qas.question: What term have Anthropologists employed to refer to the Eriksonian idea of selfhood?
Modern concerns with ethnicity and social movements in the 1970's led what group to be more interested in identity?
Until recently, what approach was used to refer to qualities of sameness in relation to a person's connection to others?

context: Anthropologists have most frequently employed the term '<a0_0>identity<a0_0/>' to refer to this idea of selfhood in a loosely Eriksonian way (Erikson 1972) properties based on the uniqueness and individuality which makes a person distinct from others. Identity became of more interest to <a1_0>anthropologists<a1_0/> with the emergence of modern concerns with ethnicity and social movements in the 1970s. This was reinforced by an appreciation, following the trend in sociological thought, of the manner in which the individual is affected by and contributes to the overall social context. At the same time, <a2_0>the Eriksonian approach<a2_0/> to identity remained in force, with the result that identity has continued until recently to be used in a largely socio-historical way to refer to qualities of sameness in relation to a person's connection to others and to a particular group of people.
